body.p:
The Occident for May only
reached here yesterday afternoon. I have read
the first portion of the Biography published, and
find a few errors which I note elsewhere. I
perceive a query has been attached to an extract
from one of my ancestors (7 lines from ?)
If this is done purposely, I assure you the
extract is quite in the good old style, and this
leads me to ask you to communicate with me
if you observe anything in the M.S. you do not
clearly make out or do not wish to publish.
I send you herewith another instalment that
you may have time to write me before
going to press, as I have a weakness in always
wishing to see my M.S. published without added
comment. Private remarks I will always gladly
receive.

In printing off the sheets for
a pamphlet, I trust you will omit the
headings either “The Occident” or “Biography &c”
and insert the proper pages. I need scarcely
add that I trust the matter will run on
so as not to appear having been published
at intervals. Although intended for presentation
to the family & friends of my father ?, still
I would like the Biography to appear in neat

body.p:
I have had to delay sending you the MS of the Biography, I am getting it copied at Mrs
De Sola's leisure (I hate copying) having feared the first part sent you had gone wrong. I have
also been closely engaged these last few weeks.

form, & as I before said, not as if it had
appeared in the Occident.

I have made a search for
some memorandum or record of payment of
Mrs Nadpers Occident a/c and find none. The
fact is I never make entries of monies received
and paid out for others. I have almost
invariably paid to Mr J A Joseph any amount
—and these have been but few—I have
received for you, except in one or two
instances when I sent you money by
Mrs Cohen or Issak Joseph. I went to
Mr Joseph and got his clerk and afterward
himself to look through his books, but
found nothing. He also has not been accustomed
to make such entires. As I before wrote
you I recollect very well Mrs A. having
paid me—tho' I forgot how much and when.
I now find in a list made by Mr J. Mrs
Nadper is credited in a memorandum in
my own writing with payment of $9—but
no mention of the amount having been
remitted you—this however I have never
mentioned in any other case. When you
send your account for the Prayer books
please add Mrs N's $9 and I will pay
you in greenbacks the amount; i.e. if you
do not object to receive it in your currency.
You ask what Benjamins owe. Here it is.

Piddian & Warner went to the States without saying
Hebrew either to you or to me; to whom they
were both indebted. Mrs Jno Levey is in New York
and Mr Isaacs could, I fancy, collect the amount
better in N. Y. than we could in Canada. Noff?
is too honest to pay, he left Montreal with his
family some months since, was obliged to come?
back here to escape Fort Lafayette and has
now made tracks for the old country where
he will be safe perhaps. He is a Hebrew, and you
need expect nothing from him. It is true you
number is here small; but better have a few
than the “shuimens? just noticed”—many however
subscribe to papers here & pay; but they nearly
all prefer the “weeklies.” The Messenger, the
Israelite, & particularly the Chronicle which is
popular here, have their subscribers—and there
is no increase in our reading population.
By the way please let me know how we stand,
Have you sold all the Calendars, & do you want
any more? Sanatary Institutions?

Mrs A. Joseph (Quebec) keeps
the pair bibles & will remit you for them. I write him

to do so today. I am not quite sure how
many copies of the Biography in pamphlet form
you intend to print. In one letter you say it will be one hundred
in another two hundred & fifty. Your figures
and (don't be offended) your writing like my
own is not always the clearest. Pray let
it be two hundred & fifty. Did you get my letter
wherein I request you to send the Prayer Books, and
tell you, you can add in a few Daily Books (Post ?)

I had the honor of giving the address
to the Graduates of Mc Gill University before the annual convocation on 3d inst.
It was gratifying to me, the occasion being an universal
one, and evincing the liberality of the college authorities
for tho' there are Jewish Professors, I believe no
one has ever yet been entrusted with giving parting
moral advice to graduates—advice one would
suppose they would insist upon being based on that
“formal?” gospel. It gave satisfaction, and the
authorities complemented me asking me for the address
for publication. This is the first year they will issue
all in pamphlet form the proceedings of convocation
with addresses &c. The Editor of the Gazette who is
a Graduate of the university asked me for the address to
publish in his columns, I send you a copy to transfer
to the Occident if you think it worth doing so. The
remarks are of course applicable to Jewish young men
and you will see I did not forget the Hebrew on physical
training—tho' practically I find Juden too lazy
to make good athlete. If I dont close you
wont read any more; so farewell for the present
and let me hear soon from you
